data:
Common Goal 1: End all forms of poverty everywhere

Specific Objective 1.2: Nationally implement appropriate social security systems and measures for all, including social protection floor policies, and achieve substantial coverage by 2030 tell the poor and vulnerable (Global Target 1.3)

Indicator 1.2.2. Number of people entitled to social insurance, health insurance and unemployment insurance

June 2021

Vietnam Social Security

No. 7 Trang Thi, Hoan Kiem District, Hanoi City

bhxh@vss.gov.vn

a) Number of people entitled to social insurance

Number of people entitled to social insurance is the number of people who have participated in social insurance and receive social insurance money (calculated by number of people, regardless of whether a person receives different types of social insurance).

Number of people entitled to social insurance paid under the following regimes: Sickness, maternity; occupational accidents, occupational diseases; retire; death death.

b) Number of people entitled to health insurance

Number of people entitled to health insurance is the number of people who have joined health insurance when going for medical examination and treatment and are entitled to medical examination and treatment services (calculated according to the number of visits of medical examination and treatment covered by health insurance).

c) Number of people entitled to unemployment insurance

Number of people entitled to unemployment insurance is the number of people who have paid unemployment insurance premiums when they lose their jobs (unemployed) and are entitled to the unemployment insurance regime (calculated according to the number of people entitled to unemployment insurance).

National level statistical reporting mode.

The national statistical reporting regime was issued under Decree No. 60/2018/ND-CP dated April 20, 2018. According to regulations, Vietnam Social Insurance collects the form “00.3N/BCB-BHXH - Number of people entitled to social insurance, unemployment insurance, health insurance”. The report is calculated starting from January 1 to the end of December 31. Periodically, Vietnam Social Insurance aggregates data from Social Security of provinces/cities directly under the Central Government and sends it to the General. Department of Statistic. After that, the General Statistics Office appraises the data according to the provisions of the Statistics Law and publishes the data on "Number of people receiving social insurance, health insurance and unemployment insurance".

Year

Vietnam Social Security

Vietnam Social Security

This indicator reflects the results of the implementation of social welfare policies for those participating in social insurance, health insurance and unemployment insurance.

Figures are published annually from 2010-2018.

Detailed data for each subgroup has not been published.

(Published source: Statistical Yearbook of the General Statistics Office).

Similar to VSDGI 1.2.1, this indicator reflects part of the global SDG target “1.3.1. Proportion of population covered by social protection floors/systems, by sex, distinguishing children, unemployed persons, older persons, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, newborns, work-injury victims and the poor and the vulnerable”.

Due to the specificity of Vietnam, there is no clear concept of the term "social protection". Social protection is close to the concept of social assistance, which is one of the three basic pillars of the welfare system. With the purpose of overcoming risks, social assistance together with social insurance have the function of reducing risks, and proactive labor market policies to prevent risks for people. Therefore, to replace the global indicator 1.3.1, Vietnam uses this indicator along with some related indicators of Vietnam such as:

1.2.1. Number of people paying social insurance, health insurance and unemployment insurance

1.2.3. Number of people receiving monthly social support in the community.

1.2.4. Number of people receiving unexpected social support

1.2.5. Number of people being concentratedly raised in social protection establishments and social houses
